title: Non-Sexual Touch
description: Explore how you experience everyday physical affection

questions.text: Casual touch from my partner—a hand on my back, a brush of fingers—feels connecting.

therapeutic.rationale: Casual, everyday touch maintains connection between more intimate moments. When small touches feel connecting, the relationship has a warm physical baseline.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If casual touch doesn't feel connecting for one partner, explore what it does feel like. Some need different types of touch to feel connection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual connection through casual touch creates an ongoing physical bond.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What everyday touches from your partner make you feel connected?

questions.text: I enjoy physical affection that isn't leading anywhere.

therapeutic.rationale: Affection without expectation creates safety. When touch always leads somewhere, some partners feel they can't relax into simple closeness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't enjoy non-escalating affection, explore what's behind that. Do they feel it should lead somewhere? Does it feel incomplete?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared enjoyment of affection for its own sake creates more opportunities for connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about physical affection that's just for closeness, not leading anywhere?

questions.text: My partner's touch throughout the day reminds me I matter to them.

therapeutic.rationale: Touch as a reminder of mattering fulfills a deep attachment need. These small physical bids say 'I'm thinking of you' without words.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If touch doesn't communicate mattering for one partner, explore what would. They may need different expressions of care.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of mattering through touch strengthens your daily connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner's touch make you feel throughout the day?

questions.text: I feel comfortable with how much physical affection we share day-to-day.

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort with the amount of everyday affection suggests alignment. Discomfort—wanting more or less—signals a conversation worth having.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different comfort levels indicate different needs. Neither is wrong, but the gap needs acknowledgment and negotiation.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort with your level of everyday affection creates ease.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Would you like more, less, or different everyday physical affection?

questions.text: Physical affection flows naturally between us.

therapeutic.rationale: Natural flow suggests comfort and attunement. When affection feels forced or awkward, something in the dynamic may need attention.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If affection doesn't flow naturally for one partner, explore what interrupts the flow. Self-consciousness? Uncertainty about welcome?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared experience of natural flow indicates comfortable physical connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When does physical affection flow most naturally between you?
